subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Milligan poems
msgSnippet: John: If what you say regarding non-native speakers is correct (I have no personal experience with this), might that not be because they have struggled to
messageBody:
John:

If what you say regarding non-native speakers is correct (I have no
personal experience with this), might that not be because they have
struggled to learn a ridiculously arcane, illogical system, and then you
throw a curve ball at them by suggesting an occasional logical change to
what they have already attempted to commit to memory when they have
previously seen no logic to English spelling?

By the way, I had no difficulty reading your post in Regularized Inglish.

Paige

John Cowan wrote:

standardized spellings wood still be important on international mailing
>
> lists like this wun: my experience is that non-nativ speakers in
> particular, no matter how good their knolledge ov written Inglish,
> ar typically baffled by even minor and sensible chainges in spelling.
>
> (This post is written in a modified form ov the American flavor ov Axel
> Wijk's Regularized Inglish.)
>
> --
> John Cowan cowan@... <mailto:cowan%40ccil.org>
> "Mr. Lane, if you ever wish anything that I can do, all you will have
> to do will be to send me a telegram asking and it will be done."
> "Mr. Hearst, if you ever get a telegram from me asking you to do
> anything, you can put the telegram down as a forgery."
>
>

John:

If what you say regarding non-native speakers is correct (I have no 
personal experience with this), might that not be because they have 
struggled to learn a ridiculously arcane, illogical system, and then you 
throw a curve ball at them by suggesting an occasional logical change to 
what they have already attempted to commit to memory when they have 
previously seen no logic to English spelling?

By the way, I had no difficulty reading your post in Regularized Inglish.

Paige
